diagnosticTool.summaryHeading: Here's an overview of your answers

elements.hint: Select ONE ONLY
elements.text: Where do most of your sales take place?

optionElements.text: Online
In person
Online and in person

elements.hint: sector
elements.text: Which sector do you operate in?

optionElements.text: Agriculture, Forestry and Fishing
Mining, Quarrying and Utilities.
Manufacturing
Construction
Wholesale and Retail Trade
Transportation and Storage
Accommodation and Food Service
Information and Communication
Financial and Insurance
Real Estate
Professional, Scientific and Technical
Administrative and Support Service
Public Administration and Defence
Education
Health and Social Work
Arts, Entertainment and Recreation
Other services

elements.hint: Select ONE ONLY
elements.text: How does your business currently use software?

optionElements.resultPageLabel: want to start using software in your business
optionElements.text: We don't use software

optionElements.resultPageLabel: use some software and want more
optionElements.text: We use some software and want more

optionElements.resultPageLabel: already use digital ways of working and are looking for replacements
optionElements.text: All processes are digital. We're looking for replacements

elements.hint: Select ONE ONLY
elements.text: What kind of IT support do you have in place?

optionElements.text: We have someone / an in-house team
We have an external team who support us
We rely on supplier support
We don't have any support in place
Friends / family help when we need it

elements.hint: Select all that apply
elements.text: How do you currently store most of your business information?

optionElements.text: On stickies and in notebooks
On individual computer hard drives
On shared hard drives
On Cloud storage (e.g. iCloud)

steps.title: What you need & want to achieve

elements.hint: Select ONE ONLY
elements.text: Do you know which software you need?

optionElements.text: Yes
No

steps.title: What you need & want to achieve

elements.hint: Select all that apply
elements.text: What type of software are you looking for?

optionElements.text: Customer relationship management (CRM)
eCommerce
Digital accounting
Something else
optionElements.additionalInfoText: If your software type isn't listed here, please tell us the type of software you're interested in.

steps.title: What you need & want to achieve

elements.hint: Select all that apply
elements.text: Which tasks do you want to simplify?

optionElements.text: Taking payments and listing products for sale
optionElements.hint: Taking payments and listing products for sale
optionElements.ResultPageLabel: taking payments and listing products for sale

optionElements.text: Selling through the business' website
Creating personalised, online customer experiences
Digital tax and accounting
Managing sales info, receipts and invoices
optionElements.hint: Managing sales info, receipts and invoices
optionElements.ResultPageLabel: managing sales info, receipts, and invoices

optionElements.text: Tracking stock levels
Monitoring sales and promotions
Understanding customer needs and trends
Tracking communication between the team and customers
optionElements.hint: Tracking communication between the team and customers
optionElements.ResultPageLabel: tracking communication between the team and customers

optionElements.text: None of these
optionElements.additionalInfoText: If your goal isn't listed here, please tell us what you're looking to achieve.

steps.title: Your digital journey
steps.summaryTitle: You are most interested in digital adoption that helps you to

elements.hint: Choose all options that you'd like to explore
elements.text2: Which benefits(s) of digital working are you most interested in?

optionElements.text: Finding new business opportunities
Increasing sales
Saving time by automating tasks
Viewing business data in real-time

steps.title: Your digital journey
steps.summaryTitle: The most time-consuming task(s) or area of your business that you'd like to simplify are:

elements.hint: Think about how you/your team work at the moment. What are the most time consuming tasks or parts of the business that you'd like to make easier.
elements.text2: Describe your business' biggest friction point that you'd like to fix.

steps.title: Your digital journey
steps.summaryTitle: Thinking about how your business currently uses software, you said

elements.hint: This could include using email, video calls, accounting software or taking online payments for your goods/services.
elements.text2: To what extent does your business currently use software and digital ways of working?

optionElements.text: We don't use any software at all
We use some software, but would like to use more
optionElements.ResultPageLabel: we use some software and want more

optionElements.text: We use lots of software packages, but are considering alternatives
optionElements.ResultPageLabel: we use lots of software. We're considering replacements

steps.title: Your digital journey
steps.summaryTitle: You currently use the following methods to share or store information:

elements.hint: Think about the job roles in your business and how you store and share your important information.
elements.hint2: Select all the options you use.
elements.text2: How do you / your team currently store and share information?

optionElements.text: In person, sticky notes and emails
optionElements.hint: In person, sticky notes and emails
optionElements.ResultPageLabel: in person, sticky notes and/or emails

optionElements.text: Through a shared database (like a Customer Relationship Management tool)
optionElements.hint: Through a shared database (like a Customer Relationship Management tool)
optionElements.ResultPageLabel: using shared databases like a CRM tool

optionElements.text: Through daily / weekly meetings
Through Word or Excel documents
Something else
optionElements.additionalInfoText: How else do you and your team store and share information?

steps.title: Your digital journey
steps.summaryTitle: Finally, when asked what you considered the biggest benefit to your business would be from digital adoption, you said

elements.text2: Describe below the benefits you think digital adoption would bring for your business.

elements.hint: Technology could be software like CRM, and/or standard office tools like Excel, email or video calls.
elements.subText: Question1: Do you currently use technology to communicate with customers, suppliers and your team?

optionElements.text: we use technology to manage and track conversations between teams, and suppliers and customers
we use some standard software like email and spreadsheets.
we don't use any technology. Communication takes by phone or face-to-face. We record and store details of conversations on paper.
Finding new business opportunities
optionElements.hint: Is improving how you communicate a business priority?
optionElements.ResultPageLabel: Improving communication with customers and your team

elements.hint: A Server would include in-house or offsite hard drives that can be accessed by you and you team. Cloud relates to virtual storage available through your hardware.
elements.subText: Question 2: Do you use Servers or the Cloud to store your data?

optionElements.text: all our business data is stored in the Cloud or on Servers.
some data is stored in the Cloud or on Servers, but some is kept on individual devices.
we don't use the Cloud or Servers at all.
Is improving data storage a business priority?
optionElements.hint: Is improving data storage a business priority?

elements.hint: This may include software that allows you to take payment through your website, or merchants like PayPal. It could also include accounting software that automatically raises invoices for your services.
elements.subText: Question 3: Do you use software to take payments online, or raise and send invoices?

optionElements.text: we use technology to take payments online and generate receipts/raise and send invoices.
we take some digital payments, but also accept cash. Receipts and invoices are created manually.
payments are either by cash or taken by card over the phone. Receipts/invoices are created manually.
Is improving how you take payments a business priority?
optionElements.hint: Is improving how you take payments a business priority?

elements.hint: This could be social media, blogging, advertising on other industry websites and/or directory listings.
elements.subText: Question 4: Does your business advertise online?

optionElements.text: we regularly use a range of online marketing tools. It's a big part of our advertising.
we have social media accounts and have advertised in the past, but don't do it regularly.
we don't use online marketing tools.
Is improving your online marketing a business priority?
optionElements.hint: Is improving your online marketing a business priority?

elements.hint: This could be a single page that explains what your business does, or a website that hosts a full catalogue of your products services. Customers could find it through a URL unique to your business or through an online marketplace like Etsy.
elements.subText: Question 5: Do you have an online shop front or website that promotes your business?

optionElements.text: we have an online presence we regularly update.
we have an online presence, but the information on it is old and we don't update it.
we don't have an online presence of any sort.
Is creating an online presence a business priority?
optionElements.hint: Is creating an online presence a business priority?

elements.hint: For example, software that creates a newsletter or promotional email, and automatically fills in the customer's name for a personal touch.
elements.subText: Question 6: Does your business use software to personalise messages to your customers?

optionElements.text: we use software to personalise all  digital marketing messages.
we use free, web-based tools to personalise some marketing messages, but don't have the software in-house.
we don't use software to personalise our marketing.
Is creating a personalised marketing experience a business priority?
optionElements.hint: Is creating a personalised marketing experience a business priority?
optionElements.ResultPageLabel: Create personalised experiences for your customers

elements.hint: These tasks could include: managing appointments; planning an event calendar; monitoring staff holidays; or recording how long it takes to complete a job.
elements.subText: Question 7: Does your business use software to carry out business and task planning?

optionElements.text: we use software for all aspects of business planning and monitoring.
we use software for some areas of the business, but not all.
we don't use software. Planning takes place in meetings and is written down.
Is automating workload and task planning a business priority?
optionElements.hint: Is automating workload and task planning a business priority?

elements.hint: This might include training to use software for a day-to-day job, or specialist training such as fire safety or risk assessment.
elements.subText: Question 8: Do you/your team use digital training when they need to learn new skills?

optionElements.text: there's support in place so everyone has access to online learning when they need it.
online training is offered as a cost-effective alternative to on-site training, but is not used as standard.
digital training is not offered.
Is digital training a business priority?
optionElements.hint: Is digital training a business priority?

elements.hint: This includes any format of digital sharing, including spreadsheets, email, CRM or via shared documents. If you work alone, think about how you record data should you need to share it in the future.
elements.subText: Question 9: Do you use software to share information with other people in the business?

optionElements.text: there's software in place so information can be stored, shared, accessed and updated across all teams.
information is stored digitally, but sharing is limited and updates need to be recorded manually.
information is shared and stored in hard copy.
Is information sharing a business priority?
optionElements.hint: Is information sharing a business priority?
optionElements.ResultPageLabel: Improve how information is shared in your business

elements.hint: It's really important to understand how you want software to make life easier. What is your end goal?
elements.hint2: Do you want to enhance your customer service, promote your goods/services, or would you like better oversight of your finances?
elements.subText: 1. Think about why you need software

optionElements.text: by making a list of what you want your new software to achieve.
optionElements.ResultPageLabel: Here's what you want your software to achieve...

optionElements.text: what are the must have features? This could include an easy to use dashboard for tracking sales, email automation or ability to share information between your team(s).
optionElements.ResultPageLabel: This is your list of must-have features...

optionElements.text: based on the types of software you ve researched, which type(s) do you think will help meet your goal(s)?
optionElements.ResultPageLabel: Here's a list of software you feel will help you reach your goal...

elements.hint: Making sure your team can access new software is vital to success. This may mean buying new hardware, reviewing how information is stored and the speed of your internet connection.
elements.subText: 2. Consider how people will access the software

optionElements.text: with a list who'll need access to the software.
optionElements.ResultPageLabel: Here's a list of who will need to use software...

optionElements.text: work out what hardware you need to order.
optionElements.ResultPageLabel: This is the hardware you need to order...

optionElements.text: work out how much budget you need to set aside. Also list how long it ll take to get these assets in place.
optionElements.ResultPageLabel: You calculated how much budget, and time, you'd need to get these assets into place...

elements.hint: Understanding the potential risks you face in a rollout, and knowing what your plans A, B and C look like, can stop you having to abort the launch altogether.

optionElements.text: by writing down the risks you might encounter. This could include; technical hiccups on the day you go live or disruption to how you usually trade. Your list should include the worst-case scenario - having to stop the rollout. What would need to happen for this to be the only solution?
optionElements.ResultPageLabel: The risks you think you might encounter are...

optionElements.text: decide how you could compensate for each risk. For example, would you be able to revert back to your old ways of working? Who will make the decisions in each case?
optionElements.ResultPageLabel: Here's what you said about compensating for each risk...

optionElements.text: how much contingency time and budget would be needed in each of these scenarios?
optionElements.ResultPageLabel: This is the amount of contingency time and budget you estimated would be needed in each scenario...

elements.hint: Identifying early on who needs information, when they need it and how you'll send it is vital, particularly if they're not used to digital ways of working.
elements.subText: 1. Keep your team(s) in the loop

optionElements.text: by identifying who's affected and how, including teams who might not be adopting your software, but could be affected by it.
plan when you'll communicate the change. List each milestone that you'll communicate to the business.
decide when you need to communicate. You might have different dates for different teams.

elements.hint: If you're looking to adopt more digital ways of working, even a slight interruption to business as usual can really impact customer service.
elements.hint2: With this in mind, think about how youd want to tell your customers about the changes, and whether you need to.

optionElements.text: by considering how your customers could be impacted by your changes. Is the new software youre integrating likely to impact the service they receive? If so, make a list here of how that could happen.

write a list of what you think they'll need to know about the changes. For example, is a department they usually deal with likely to be less available for while? Will the new software change how they contact or pay your business?
decide when you need to communicate the changes to your customers. You might have different dates for different customers.

elements.hint: Youll also need a list of key dates for communicating your roll out. This will help you meet specific milestones, and give your staff and customers clarity of whats changing across your business.

optionElements.text: by reviewing the two lists youve made above and pick out the key events and dates you need to communicate to your team and customers.
decide how you will communicate. You might choose different methods for different messages.
choose who will take responsibility for these communications including how they will deal with queries.

elements.hint: As this is your first software rollout, its important to receive as much help as you can.

optionElements.text: by thinking about your technical strengths and weaknesses. Write down the areas youd like help with.
make a list of who could provide support. Is there someone on your team who can help? Or will you rely on your supplier?
add how much time and budget would be needed for the support youre opting for.

elements.hint: Things dont always run smoothly first time. How will you plan for bug fixes when you first launch, or for any that crop up after afterwards?

optionElements.text: by thinking about how youll deal with any bugs in the software you roll out. As with integration, will you have someone in-house or rely on your supplier?
consider the type of support you think youll need. This could be on-going, as and when is needed, or having someone in-house.
think about how bugs will be reported. Who will be responsible for this within your business?

elements.hint: Unlike bug fixes, maintenance should be less of a surprise.

optionElements.text: by thinking about how much maintenance youll likely need for your new software. This could include updates, patches and how you tackle cyber security. Information provided by your supplier will help here.
review the list and see if anyone in your business could be responsible for certain parts. Does the software youre buying include automatic updates for the areas mentioned above?
draw out the maintenance issues for your new software that you're likely to face and list how these needs could be met, either in-house or by your supplier.

elements.hint: Understanding who could help with training your team(s) on new software and hardware - either internally or externally - can make all the difference to achieving a successful rollout.

optionElements.text: by looking at the team(s) you already have in place. Can you utilise anyone in your business? Or is it best to enlist external support?
make a list of who needs training and whether it will be for software, as well as new hardware.
look for opportunities where people in-house can be trained to train others, then make a separate list of who youll need to arrange external training for.

elements.hint: Thinking about how best to offer training, together with cost, can help steer you for your new roll out.

optionElements.text: by thinking about how you want to train your team. Write down a list of pros and cons for each format (i.e. virtual, on-site, off-site).
speak to your team(s) about which type of training works best for them. Make a list of their preferred methods, including what doesnt work for them.
see what training is available for your new software. Review this with the budget youve set aside for training to identify whats realistic.

elements.hint: As with your current staff, planning in advance how to train new starters in your business on software keeps things running smoothly.

optionElements.text: by making a list of which job roles would use the software. This will help you flag up who needs training after recruitment.
as with your current team, think about the best time for training to take place and how long it will take to get a new starter up to speed.
make a list of the experience an ideal new starter would have, or how many hours training you want to include in an induction period.

elements.hint: Testing for bugs and usability dont always give the same results. Think about how you want to test and how much time you want to dedicate to the process.

optionElements.text: by making two lists of testers. The first are people who can look for bugs in the software. The second are users who may not be as tech-savvy, but will be using the software every day.
list how much time you would like to give each group to identify any problems in how the system works, or blockers in their confidence to use it.
identify testing champions from each group. These will be the people youll brief later and engage with to gather your feedback.

elements.hint: Understanding how your team(s) feel about the rollout and software, before and during the process can drive a better, smoother outcome.

optionElements.text: by choosing feedback champions to collect all feedback, who can take responsibility for grouping topics together and prioritising their importance.
speak to your feedback champions and ask how much time they would need for this task. Do they need cover on their day job? If so, who could provide that support for them?
working with your feedback champions, ask if theres any preferred way theyd like to receive and store the feedback. Make a list here.

elements.hint: Prioritise and schedule how you want to implement feedback. What needs to happen before launch, and what can wait until after?

optionElements.text: by making a list of what the most useful type of feedback for a successful rollout would look like.
prioritise this list. It will help you decide which feedback needs addressing before launch, and what can wait until after. It also supports your feedback champion(s) to organise their workload.

plot out how you would like your feedback champion(s) to review and discuss any issues with you. Does a weekly face-to-face meeting work? Or are there some issues youd want flagging immediately? Make a list here.

elements.hint: With digital ways of working already part of your business, chances are you have a lot of the infrastructure you need already in place.
elements.hint2: This section is designed to help you identify wholl be using the new software, and assess your hardware needs correctly.
elements.subText: 1. Consider how people will access the software

optionElements.text: with a list who'll need access to the software.
find out what hardware you need to order so that each person can access the software. Add it to the list.
work out how much budget you need to assign for this and time to get these assets in place.

elements.hint: Understanding the potential risks you face in a roll out, and knowing what your plans A, B and C look like, can stop you having to abort the launch altogether.

optionElements.text: by writing down the risks you might encounter, such as data loss or interruption to trading. Your list should include the worst-case scenario  having to stop the rollout. What would need to happen for this to be the only solution?
decide how you could mitigate each risk. What resources will you need and who will make the decisions in each case?
How much contingency time and budget would be needed in each of these scenarios?

elements.hint: As with identifying potential risks, understanding the ways your new software can indirectly impact your business will help smooth the transition to a new way of working.

optionElements.text: by thinking how the rollout could have a knock-on effect on each team and your business operations.
decide how you could protect against these negative effects.
add a rough estimate of time, effort and budget to compensate for these impacts.

elements.hint: Identifying who needs information early on, when they need it and how youll send it, provides you with a roadmap of when to reach out.
elements.subText: 1. Keep your team(s) in the loop

optionElements.text: by making a list of who needs to be told about the new software. This will include individuals and teams who may be impacted by using the software every day, or occasionally.
think about when you need to tell each group about the change. Look back at your last rollout, are there any lessons learned you can include here?
decide how you want to communicate to each group. This could be a combination of face-to-face and email.

elements.hint: As youll know from previous changes to your ways of working, a slight interruption to business as usual can really impact customer service.

optionElements.text: by considering how your customers could be impacted by your changes. Is the new software youre integrating likely to impact the service they receive? If so, make a list here of how that could happen.

write a list of what you think they'll need to know about the changes. For example, is a department they usually deal with likely to be less available for while? Will the new software change how they contact or pay your business?
decide when you need to communicate with them and how. You might have different dates and methods for different customers.

elements.hint: Youll also need a list of key dates for communicating your roll out. This will help you meet specific milestones, and give your staff and customers clarity of whats changing across your business.

optionElements.text: by reviewing the two lists youve made above and pick out the key events and dates you need to communicate to your team and customers.
decide how you will communicate. You might choose different methods for different messages.
choose who will take responsibility for these communications including how they will deal with queries.

elements.hint: When you last added new software, did you need extra support to get it working with your systems? Was there anything you didnt consider last time around, that youd do differently now?

optionElements.text: by reviewing how you integrated software last time. Write down the things that worked well and any pitfalls you can correct this time.
make a list of who could provide this support. Is there someone on your team who can help? Or would it be easier to talk to your supplier about supporting integration?
add how much time and cost would be needed for the integration support you opt for.

elements.hint: As youll know, things dont always run smoothly first time. Like support for integration, how will you plan for bug fixes when you first launch, or for any that crop up after launch?

optionElements.text: by looking at how you deal with bugs in the software you use at the moment. If there are people in your business who provide support, make a list of them here. If youve got supplier support, write down what they offer and if you had to change the level of service they provided.
consider which elements of your existing set-up you want to keep and those youd change.
review if your chosen method of support  in-house or supplier support  match up where these elements are being met, and if theres anything youd like to improve on.

elements.hint: You may have ongoing support from your last integration, in which case you can use this as a baseline for your new software.

optionElements.text: by making a list of how you currently maintain all the software and hardware in your business. This should include software updates, patches and how you tackle cyber security.
review the list and see if your new software could be included in this existing plan.  Does the software youre buying include automatic updates for the areas mentioned above?
draw out the maintenance issues for your new software that are unlikely to be covered and list how these needs could be met, either in-house or by your supplier.

elements.hint: Understand if your existing training approach can support your new software. Then look for the gaps you need to fill.

optionElements.text: by looking at the talent you already have in place. Make a note of the person/people who are already supporting other members of the team.
think about who needs training and whether it will be for software and new hardware.
look for areas where your people in-house can train others, then make a separate list of who youll need to arrange external training for.

elements.hint: Reviewing how youve trained staff in the past and measuring its effectiveness, together with cost, can help steer you for your new rollout.

optionElements.text: by thinking about how youve trained for new software in the past. Write down a list of pros and cons for each format (i.e. virtual, on-site, off-site).
speak to your team(s) about which type of training works best for them. Make a list of their preferred methods, including what doesnt work for them.
see what training is available for your new software. Review this with the budget youve set aside for training to identify whats realistic.

elements.hint: As with your previous software integrations, having a plan to train new starters keeps things running smoothly.

optionElements.text: by making a list of which job roles would use the software. This will help you flag up who needs training after recruitment.
speak to the team members who have supported training in the past. Ask how long it would realistically take to get a new starter up to speed.
make a list of the experience an ideal new starter would have, or how many hours training you want to include in an induction period.

elements.hint: Testing for bugs and usability dont yield the same results. Reflect on how youve tested in the past, how long it took and if theres anything youd do differently this time.

optionElements.text: by making two lists of testers. The first are people who can look for bugs in the software. The second are users who may not be as tech-savvy, but will be using the software every day.
list how much time you would like to give each group to identify any problems in how the system works, or blockers in their confidence to use it.
identify testing champions from each group. These will be the people youll brief later and engage with to gather your feedback.

elements.hint: Utilise the power of your feedback by gathering it in a way that makes it easy to anaylse.

optionElements.text: by choosing feedback champions to collect all feedback, who can take responsibility for grouping topics together and prioritising their importance.
speak to your feedback champions and ask how much time they would need for this task. Do they need cover on their day job? If so, who could provide that support for them?
working with your feedback champions, ask if theres any preferred way theyd like to receive and store the feedback. Make a list here.

elements.hint: Prioritise and schedule how you want to implement feedback. What needs to happen before launch, and what can wait until after?

optionElements.text: by listing what you consider to be the most important feedback for a successful rollout. Think about whats happened in past software adoptions, particularly if caused disruption to trading.
prioritise this list. It will help you decide which feedback needs addressing before launch, and what can wait until after. It also supports your feedback champion(s) to organise their workload.

plot out how you would like your feedback champion(s) to review and discuss any issues with you. Does a weekly face-to-face meeting work? Or are there some issues youd want flagging immediately? Make a list here.

elements.hint: This section is designed to help you identify wholl be using the new software, and assess your hardware needs correctly.
elements.subText: 1. Consider how people will access the software

optionElements.text: with a list who'll need access to the software.
find out what hardware you need to order so that each person can access the software. Add it to the list.
work out how much budget you need to assign for this and time to get these assets in place.

elements.hint: Understanding the potential risks you face in a roll out, and knowing what your plans A, B and C look like, can stop you having to abort the launch altogether.

optionElements.text: by writing down the risks you might encounter, such as data loss or interruption to trading. Your list should include the worst-case scenario  having to stop the rollout. What would need to happen for this to be the only solution?
decide how you could mitigate each risk. What resources will you need and who will make the decisions in each case?
How much contingency time and budget would be needed in each of these scenarios?

elements.hint: These impacts may include extra burden on other teams when you have staff in training.

optionElements.text: by thinking how the rollout could have a knock-on effect on each team and your business operations.
decide how you could protect against these negative effects.
add a rough estimate of time, effort and budget to compensate for these impacts.

elements.hint: When you last rolled out new software, were there any parts of your business that felt unprepared? How can you improve communication for this rollout?
elements.subText: 1. Keep your team(s) in the loop

optionElements.text: by making a list of who needs to be told about the new software. This will include individuals and teams who may be impacted by using the software every day, or occasionally.
think about when you need to tell each group about the change. Look back at your last rollout, are there any lessons learned you can include here?
decide how you want to communicate to each group. This could be a combination of face-to-face and email.

elements.hint: As youll know from previous changes to your ways of working, a slight interruption to business as usual can really impact customer service.

optionElements.text: by considering how your customers could be impacted by your changes. Is the new software youre integrating likely to impact the service they receive? If so, make a list here of how that could happen.

write a list of what you think they'll need to know about the changes. For example, is a department they usually deal with likely to be less available for while? Will the new software change how they contact or pay your business?
decide when you need to communicate with them and how. You might have different dates and methods for different customers.

elements.hint: Youll also need a list of key dates for communicating your roll out. This will help you meet specific milestones, and give your staff and customers clarity of whats changing across your business.

optionElements.text: by reviewing the two lists youve made above and pick out the key events and dates you need to communicate to your team and customers.
decide how you will communicate. You might choose different methods for different messages.
choose who will take responsibility for these communications including how they will deal with queries.

elements.hint: When you last added new software, did you need extra support to get it working with your systems? Was there anything you didnt consider last time around, that youd do differently now?

optionElements.text: by making a list of what tech support will be provided by the software suppliers, and what youll have to provide for in-house.
consider who is the best person / people to be responsible for which tasks. Make sure they have the correct expertise or training.
assign the tasks and ensure that the workload is realistic for your team.

elements.hint: As youll know, things dont always run smoothly first time. Like support for integration, how will you plan for bug fixes when you first launch, or for any that crop up after launch?

optionElements.text: by looking at how you deal with bugs in the software you use at the moment. If there are people in your business who provide support, make a list of them here. If youve got supplier support, write down what they offer and if you had to change the level of service they provided.
consider which elements of your existing set-up you want to keep and those youd change.
review if your chosen method of support  in-house or supplier support  match up where these elements are being met, and if theres anything youd like to improve on.

elements.hint: You may have ongoing support from your last integration, in which case you can use this as a baseline for your new software.

optionElements.text: by making a list of how you currently maintain all the software and hardware in your business. This should include software updates, patches and how you tackle cyber security.
review the list and see if your new software could be included in this existing plan.  Does the software youre buying include automatic updates for the areas mentioned above?
draw out the maintenance issues for your new software that are unlikely to be covered and list how these needs could be met, either in-house or by your supplier.

elements.hint: Understand if your existing training approach can support your new software. Then look for the gaps you need to fill.

optionElements.text: by listing the software functionality each team needs to be trained on and people/teams individual needs.
decide who will deliver the training and how much time and resource youll need.
roughly plan how much time you need to allow for each piece of training. Dont forget to add extra time if youll be training one person to pass their knowledge on to other team members.

elements.hint: Reviewing how youve trained staff in the past and measuring its effectiveness, together with cost, can help steer you for your new rollout.

optionElements.text: by thinking about how youve trained for new software in the past. Write down a list of pros and cons for each format (i.e. virtual, on-site, off-site).
speak to your team(s) about which type of training works best for them. Make a list of their preferred methods, including what doesnt work for them.
see what training is available for your new software. Review this with the budget youve set aside for training to identify whats realistic.

elements.hint: As with your previous software integrations, having a plan to train new starters keeps things running smoothly.

optionElements.text: by making a list of which job roles would use the software. This will help you flag up who needs training after recruitment.
speak to the team members who have supported training in the past. Ask how long it would realistically take to get a new starter up to speed.
make a list of the experience an ideal new starter would have, or how many hours training you want to include in an induction period.

elements.hint: Testing for bugs and usability dont yield the same results. Reflect on how youve tested in the past, how long it took and if theres anything youd do differently this time.

optionElements.text: by making two lists of testers. The first are people who can look for bugs in the software. The second are users who may not be as tech-savvy, but will be using the software every day.
list how much time you would like to give each group to identify any problems in how the system works, or blockers in their confidence to use it.
identify testing champions from each group. These will be the people youll brief later and engage with to gather your feedback.

elements.hint: Utilise the power of your feedback by gathering it in a way that makes it easy to anaylse.

optionElements.text: by choosing feedback champions to collect all feedback, who can take responsibility for grouping topics together and prioritising their importance.
speak to your feedback champion(s) and ask how much time they would need for this task. Do they need cover on their day job? If so, who could provide that support for them?
working with your feedback champions, ask if theres any preferred way theyd like to receive and store the feedback. Make a list here.

elements.hint: Prioritise and schedule how you want to implement feedback. What needs to happen before launch, and what can wait until after?

optionElements.text: list what you consider to be the most important feedback for a successful rollout. Think about whats happened in past software adoptions, particularly if it caused disruption to trading.
prioritise this list. It will help you decide which feedback needs addressing before launch, and what can wait until after. It also supports your feedback champion(s) to organise their workload.

plot out how you would like your feedback champion(s) to review and discuss any issues with you. Does a weekly face-to-face meeting work? Or are there some issues youd want flagging immediately? Make a list here.
